Award.AwardTitle: South Texas Aviation Maintenance Technician Education Project (STAMP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The South Texas Aviation Maintenance Technician Education Project (STAMP) by Del Mar College, a Minority and Hispanic Serving Institution, is to improve technician education in aviation maintenance technology (AMT) and avionics in community colleges and four-year institutions. Activities include development of Web-enabled, interactive educational materials; professional development for AMT educators; and recruitment and retention of students for AMT associate degree programs and transfer to a baccalaureate aviation sciences program. STAMP partner institutions include five Texas community colleges: Del Mar College (lead), Midland College, Tarrant County College, Texas State Technical College-Waco, and Texas State Technical College-West Texas, and a four-year institution Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (Daytona Beach, FL). The project will work closely with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to ensure that the AMT curriculum aligns well with the FAA certification requirements to meet the job market needs.

The project disseminates the interactive Web-based modules to community college AMT programs across Texas, and eventually to AMT programs nationally through the National Center for Aerospace and Transportation Technologies, reaching a potential 14,000 AMT students annually. The modules, developed using modern practices, expedite and improve certified aviation technician preparation for a more consistently educated technical workforce. The project shares best practices for successful recruiting strategies to bring more diverse students and veterans into AMT programs, which increases the number of students underrepresented in AMT, particularly women and Hispanic students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subject matter contained within the General courses of the Aviation Maintenance Technician (AMT) program includes six (6) fundamental courses which create the foundation of the Federal Aviation Administration Part 147 Aviation Maintenance Technician curriculum: Weight and Balance, Basic Electricity, Aviation Sciences, Ground Operations, Federal Aviation Regulations, and Shop Practices.  Through a grant funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) DUE no.  1205021 entitled South Texas Aviation Maintenance Education Program (STAMP), partnering AMT educators and institutions collectively pursued the goal to increase and diversify the number of learners enrolling and completing an Aviation Maintenance Technician (AMT) education program by enhancing the curriculum with interactive content through use of multimedia software.  In order to provide content diversity for AMT educators with recent technological and technical advances within the aviation industry, STAMP embarked on strategic partnerships offering AMT educators access to professional development opportunities to keep them abreast with current trends, practices, and technologies directly applicable to the aviation industry.  STAMP efforts also included and focused on producing web-enabled interactive learning (WEIL) modules intended to support online delivery of curriculum materials.

STAMP [The grant] achieved faculty training goals that brought about significant impacts on AMT instructors and their students.  Training impacts affected all AMT faculty who completed STAMP professional development workshops, their students, and respective colleges with AMT programs.  Six 5-day technical workshops were delivered by Year 3 of the grant and received extremely positive feedback from faculty completers.  Workshops addressed new technology, provided shop demonstrations, and engaged participants in many hours of interactive learning and hands-on practice which participants had rated to have:  (1) inspired faculty attendees to update or add to their existing course content; (2) helped students improve their job readiness, career planning, and technical ability (through the new information gained by their instructors); (3) motived faculty to implement several new hands-on learning activities in their AMT courses; (4) inspired faculty leaders to begin working on a set of “mini-courses” that will build on STAMP workshop content and integrate workshop curriculum with annual Inspection Authorization (IA) refresher training (FAA requirement); (5) encouraged faculty to share their information and methods employed at workshops with other AMT faculty; and (6) verified that AMT faculty would have attended more of the workshops if they had been provided with travel funds.  (J. Mattoon, Ph. D., STAMP External Evaluator, Final Report 2016) 

Efforts to develop web-enabled interactive learning modules initially encompassed the six (6) general courses supporting the Aviation Maintenance Technician Program until the onset of the project’s third year when shifting the development platform from Flash to HTML5 became inevitable.  This change came in response to the announced move by Adobe to discontinue its support for Adobe Flash on mobile devices.  With the project entering its third year, development efforts were reduced to the three (3) first-priority modules, namely Weight and Balance, Basic Electricity, and Aviation Sciences.  Many other changes and adjustments were adapted to cope with challenges that came with shifting the development platform from the well-established Flash to a fairly new and still unstable HTML5 environment with the project, specially with only two (2) years left in the project overall timeline.  STAMP’s work on the WEIL modules resulted in the production of a large volume of lecture- and textbook-based AMT curriculum in a format that is conducive to delivery on distance learning systems (J. Mattoon, Ph. D., STAMP External Evaluator, Final Report 2016).  With STAMP team consisting of two (2) multimedia technicians and 1 coordinator directly involved in the production process, the library of multimedia elements was built to consist of text, graphics, audio, video, and animation in formats compatible with HTML5.  Some of these were reproduced and/or converted from .swf format created before the shift to HTML5 was undertaken.   The time consuming nature of work involved in multimedia development constrained the project timeline further as hurdles came in the process of making the Flash to HTML5 platform shift. 

Partnership forged with the Center for Aviation and Automotive Technological Education Using Virtual E-Schools (CA2VES), a co-NSF grantee under Clemson University, presented a strategic solution with both parties taking initiatives to share individual project outputs in order to mutually serve respective project objectives.  STAMP’s library of aviation-related digital media assets were shared with CA2VES who in turn, will undertake further development to enable integration of these digital assets into the workflow in building courses to form part of their EducateWorkforce learning solution.  With such arrangement in place and STAMP heading towards the end of its timeline, and CA2VES opting to undertake the development process internally, STAMP project concluded with CA2VES taking over the WEIL development initiative.
